issues.description: The problem statement's UML declares ExcellenceLand.excellentEnough as a boolean, but the solution implementation declares it as a String (and the constructor and getter use String). This is a structural type mismatch: students implementing the class according to the UML (boolean) will produce a different constructor and getter signature than the provided solution, and tests that expect a boolean will fail or be confusing.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the type of excellentEnough consistent with the UML: change the type from String to boolean in ExcellenceLand (attribute declaration, constructor parameter, and getter). Update the solution (and any template/example code) so the constructor signature and getExcellentEnough() return boolean. Alternatively, if the intended type is actually String, update the problem statement/UML to specify String instead of boolean.
